text: On the day in late February when I arrive at Georgina Chapman ’ s town house in the West Village to interview her, it ’ s unseasonably hot, nearly 80 degrees. I am ushered to the parlor floor, where, even though it feels like August outside, a fire is roaring away. As I wait, it suddenly dawns on me that I am sitting in Harvey Weinstein ’ s living room. He purchased the six - story house in 2006, the year before he married Chapman, and she has since put her stamp all over it : black floors and white rugs, chinoiserie, lots of gilt and glass, hydrangeas in a vase, a Jo Malone candle burning.
